reviewText:
For a game that was created in a single week, it runs exceptionally well and is quite addictive.  This game, unlike other FPS's, take the approuch of being as real as possible: Every single thing you do with the gun is another step for you to take.  Unloading a clip?  Reloading?  Safty?  All of those need to be done one at a time.  Although this may seem risky, this game does it to a whole new level and makes it interesting.  Mechanics are a bit awkward to get a handle of at first, but after about a half hour of play-time, you begin to get the hang of it, gaining some progress in the game.  I can almost memorize all the buttons required for reloading.

Enemies are nothing special, though: they basically boil down to stationary turrets and flying robot helicopers from SpyGear with tazers that go *zap*.  Nothing unique, but far from being easy.

This game does a good job of making it a challange without making it either laughably easy or insanly hard.  At first, the game is difficult, but then you get a hang of things and it begins to get easier.  It's well paced.

Randomly generated areas also help the game's overall success.

This game is fantastic for what it is.  The best part is that I didn't even need to pay for it: They announced that if you pre-order their other game, Overgrowth" (which is an excellent game as well; I highly recomend it) you get a free copy of "Reciever" as a thank you gift.

Thanks
hoursPlayed: true
helpfulPercent: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Receiver is a game about shooting.

...

Oh, were you looking for something else? That pretty much sums up what this game is, from it's concept, of course.
Now, let's start the real review:

Graphics: Made in Unity 3D, the game has simple graphics and places that seems to be missing textures. But it's all part of the game's visual art style and concept. Enemies desing are also pretty simple and you can spot then on sight (Witch is essential in this game IMO). I guess the gun model is okay, since it gives player a good vision of what he's doing with it and where he's REALLY poiting at. Skybox is dead, but you really don't need it in this game.

Gameplay: This is the jackpot in this game. The realism put into shooting, reloading, carrying and using your gun is something so nice to see in a FPS and that even most AAA studios keep forgetting that it exists. Playing this game using the device that simulates a pistol is even better. All the controls, from the keyboard/mouse/device responds pretty well and always keeps the game fluid and dinamic.
Even tough gunplay is the biggest part of this game, it also haves an objective: Collecting all your self recordings so you can finish the game. But finding then is a pain in the ♥♥♥. Not only you don't have a radar, but you will die a ♥♥♥♥ING lot in this game. It IS hard. And i mean it. The enemies were created with the intetion of making the game hard in this way, and the AI woks pretty well to make sure that this is happening. Don't mess with the enemies. It's not because the game is realistic that the enemies will also be. 2-3 shoots and you are dead. Make sure of always keeping your ammo at count, or else, you are ♥♥♥♥ed.

Soundtrack: Missing. Even tough the self recording are pretty neat to hear, i just can't like this monotunus atmosphere. They could've put some songs like The Stanley Parable did (Or SuperHot) to don't let the player attention go away of the game. Mostly because that if you are not paying attention, you are dead.

Story: Most of it is explained through recordings. It's not a gigantic plot, but it does it job of keeping the player guessing. Going through uncovering the secrets of the protagonist organization and himself is quite awesome and it has a nice progression...When you find then in order, that's because the only bad thing is: If you die, your found recording count will reset, so, if you want to find a new one that you haven't heard yet/don't want to hear the same thing again from a past one, good luck with that.

This game is more considered a project" than a game itself. It had a nice proporsal and the idea of this game can be explored in other games (Indie or AAA). If you are looking to experience something new and a neat challenge

reviewText: Awsome game. The big boys could learn a lot from this gem. Every time I play Battlefied, Cod, whatever, and just mash R to reload I just sit and watch an amination for 2 seconds before continuing the midless spraying of bullets. Receiver doesn't just make you care about operating your weapon, It makes you care about every single bullet you fire and the target your shooting at. I would love to see main stream games taking this aproch, but sadly they are all now slaves to the consoles and their 10 to 15 button controlers. Anyway, rant over, buy this game its fun and real challange for any FPS player.\n\nA thinking man's FPS

It's not because the game is realistic that the enemies will also be. 2-3 shoots and you are dead. Make sure of always keeping your ammo at count, or else, you are ♥♥♥♥ed.

Soundtrack: Missing. Even tough the self recording are pretty neat to hear, i just can't like this monotunus atmosphere. They could've put some songs like The Stanley Parable did (Or SuperHot) to don't let the player attention go away of the game. Mostly because that if you are not paying attention, you are dead.

Story: Most of it is explained through recordings. It's not a gigantic plot, but it does it job of keeping the player guessing. Going through uncovering the secrets of the protagonist organization and himself is quite awesome and it has a nice progression...When you find then in order, that's because the only bad thing is: If you die, your found recording count will reset, so, if you want to find a new one that you haven't heard yet/don't want to hear the same thing again from a past one, good luck with that.

This game is more considered a project" than a game itself. It had a nice proporsal and the idea of this game can be explored in other games (Indie or AAA). If you are looking to experience something new and a neat challenge

reviewText:
It's pretty novel and fun but in the end if you've ever shot a real weapon it just makes you want to do that. It's kind of like a dating simulator in that you get a very rough approximation of the real thing but none of the real pleasure of it. Granted, it also comes to you very naturally if you have shot a real weapon. Also I've noticed people in the reviews complaining about the utter randomness in the game including enemies, bullets, gun you get and so forth but there's a very good reason for this and I see what the developer did here.

One of the first things that you're taught when instructed in shooting is how to check your chamber. It's important to learn because it's one of the main things you do to check if your weapon is safe or not and stops you from accidentally wasting a round. You also need to check a magazine in any gun regardless of whether or not anything is chambered. Basically it's random so you get into the routine of checking your weapon like you would in real life and it's an awesome way of pounding procedure into people's heads.

On another note you can also do a trick wherein you chamber a round, take the magazine out, then put another one in to get an extra one. In real life it's not very healthy for the magazine's spring and is one of the top 10 ways to literally shoot yourself in the foot but since this is a game go nuts.


In conclusion if you're okay with not having the actual feeling of the shot and getting to feel that pleasurable click of loading rounds and magazine insertion it's probably worth playing if you can get it cheaply. Though I'll personally probably never play it again after I get 11 tapes for the first time.

Edit: Actually cancel that, I wasn't going to mention it but it has some performance issues despite the very simple untextured geometry. It also drives my GPU temperature through the roof because of the apparent load so I'll probably not play much more of it.

reviewText:
I have to voice how impressed I am with this one. I thought this was going to be a quick pick-up-and-play novelty, but instead I found a game with an extremely complex and deep gun mechanic.

Good:

The main catch of Receiver is that it has some seriously detailed and realistic gun mechanics. You randomly start with one of three pistols, either a magnum pistol, a revolver, or an automatic handgun, in a random state with a random amount of bullets. The term 'check your weapon' seriously applies here. How many bullets are in the magazine? Is there a bullet in the chamber? Do I need to pull the slide back? Is the safety on? Is it in automatic? Each of these questions comes up each time you spawn and pick up your gun, and each function and action has a key you have to memorize.

But what really keeps getting me about this game is how creepy it is. You are, in essence, the only living thing in a randomly generated complex filled with cold robots. it is dark and almost eerie. I kept thinking to myself that this game would make an incredible horror game. This is what F.E.A.R. should have been. But, as is, it is overall very tense and does a good job of leaving a lasting impression despite being so simple in story and graphics.

I should also mention this game is very difficult in a lot of ways. You will likely die fumbling around with your pistol and trying to remember the controls. You'll curse yourself for accidentally dropping your magazine when you are trying to reload it, or while you scramble for that perfectly good bullet you ejected from your gun on accident. But the feeling of mastering your pistol is truly a reward on its own. And that doesn't even include shooting things.

Enemies are tough on that note. Robots don't die from just being shot a lot. Enemy bots have four vitals you can hit to kill or disable them: weapon, motor, battery, and camera. Precision is everything. One aimed pistol shot can render a robot useless, but madly firing at the main body will do nothing. Turrets will unleash a flurry of machinegun fire if they catch glimpse of you, and those shock drones are a whole lot faster than they look. And finally, you die in one hit, and must start over every time you are killed.

But its all good challenge, and while the complex appears to be nearly infinite, it is possible to learn the game, recognize certain consistent features, and fight off your attackers with deadly skill while you explore and search for tapes.

So, overall for the good, it has a deep gun mechanic with lots of nuances and details (which is rare that I actually like something like this), its a lot more challenging than it looks, and somehow manages to master the art of simple elegance and proficent story telling while still being very simplistic.

Bad:

I really don't like some of the randomization. One time I started within easy view of a hover drone, and prompty got zapped before I could even check my gun out. Another time I started with only two bullets in my gun and nothing else. Often times I found myself going on forever; searching out the complex without finding any of the tapes for long periods of time. A little consistency and a safe zone to start with would have been nice.

Also, I have to say while this game is fun, I feel like it is also a game I will never be able to beat. The complex is absolutely huge. I sometimes would spend several minutes gunning down robots and trying to survive; only to die with not even one tape. A radar for the little things would have been nice. Or something more than just a shiny spot. Its fun to be able to just explore blindly and figure things out on your own, but only to an extent. This goes well past that extent and into the frustrating I can't figure out how to beat this" zone.

Maybe that's part of the challenge for some

reviewText:
Sort of an FPS roguelike, you basically just wander and wander and wander looking for tapes and ammo, with no maps or any other clues to help you at all.

I enjoyed the realistc gun operation, even though it got me killed many many times.

There's basically 2 kinds of enemies, turrets and flybots, and both can 1-shot you, which can lead to some frustration.

On top of that, there's barely enough ammo to get by, and if you wander into the wrong spot and get spotted by a flybot and waste your last few bullets on it, its almost a guaranteed GG.

I eventually got bored of just randering around an RNG building, and fortunately there were some cheats available.

Even with invincibility and unlimited ammo, the game was STILL a hassle to complete. I'd spin around and empty 3-4 magazines trying to shoot 1 little drone buzzing around my head.

Eventually the game just started trolling and put 3 tapes and 5 turrets in a very small space. I have NO idea how I would have gotten past that without infinite ammo.

I don't know if I would pay $5 for this, but it's definitely an interesting little time waster.

reviewText:
Receiver is a very small game, and, in terms of the presentation, does feel a bit unfinished. This is understandable considering the very short dev. time, but it bears mentioning. For the most part, though, it's a very interesting game. Weapons handling is modeled in a way that no other game (that I'm aware of) has done. Instead of having a reload key, for example, the game has separate buttons to remove/insert magazines, pull the weapon's slide, pull back the hammer, etc. Once you get the hang of it, it makes for a really interesting, tactical experience using the game's weapons.

The game has a storyline told by finding 11 cassette tapes scattered around an environment that's randomly generated each time you play. Finding all 11 tapes requires a fair bit of exploration, and the random elements of the game give it decent replay-ability, even with only a few weapons and enemy types.

Overall it's an engaging, atmospheric game, but I wouldn’t recommend spending $5 on it. In fact I wouldn’t recommend spending any amount of money on it. The controls are as confusing as ♥♥♥♥, and you die very easily, almost impossible without mods. DONT BUY THIS GAME, BUY SOMETHING ELSE; THAT’S WORTH THE MONEY! I rate this at a 2/10.

reviewText:
Receiver's main selling point is the incredibly sophisticated firearm modelling - you can interact with most of the important bits on your handgun: safety, slide, slide lock, magazine, hammer, cylinder, down to manually inserting rounds. The detail extends to the physics engine itself, with accurate balistics, and even the enemy turrets and hoverbots, which can be partially or completely disabled depending on the area they were shot in.

At first, the controls will feel quite clunky, almost like the QWOP equivalent of shooters (which was a design intention on behalf of the developers), but eventually you develop a routine for prepping your weapon. Then the game messes up your routine in panicking moments, as a hoverbot BEEPS and rushes to taze you to death.

It's a game made in 7 days, so there's bound to be several glitches and optimisation issues, but if you can look past those it's an enjoyable experience, also doubling as a way to learn a thing or two about weapons in general.

reviewText:
Highly visceral and deep gun handling and creepy distopian vibe are the two primary positive elements that this game has to offer. Nothing beats the feeling of learning the gun mechanics and successfully using them against the (sadly) 2 types of enemies you'll face during the game.

The map is randomly generated for each playthrough and each time you die but things will definitely start to look familiar the more you play. Your mission is to locate 11 tapes that are scattered around the map and listen to their dialogue while staying alive. Be very careful while turning each corner in this game because a single enemy shot will kill you and send you back to the beginning. Oh and did I mention the guns are also randomized? There are 3 guns total but how many bullets they have and whether they're loaded, cocked or with the safety on can vary between each start.

On the negative side, there are framerate hitches whenever you walk into new areas and the levels can get really dark. The flashlight proved more of a nuisance than help because it only lights up a few feet in front of you. This could mean life or death in this game. There are no gamma settings in the game. Also, as I mentioned previously, the levels can get a bit repetitive at times because they are seemingly different pre-made areas which are stitched together in different ways because of the level generator.

All in all, a very entertaining game. Definitely get this on a sale. The adrenaline rush and realistic gun handling are definitely worth quite a few hours of random fun.

reviewText: Receiver challenges players to traverse a randomly generated landscape of buildings in search of 11 cassette tapes.  This is no simple task, with flying and stationary turrets primed and ready, permanent death in one bullet, and realistic weapons simulation, death awaits every corner.  You must learn how to manipulate every part of a weapon from pulling back the slide, ejecting the mag, and manually refilling cartridges.  What's usually simple, is suddenly a challenge in memory and nerves as you fumble to reload with death at your back.  Welcome to the real world of guns.

It's pretty novel and fun but in the end if you've ever shot a real weapon it just makes you want to do that. It's kind of like a dating simulator in that you get a very rough approximation of the real thing but none of the real pleasure of it. Granted, it also comes to you very naturally if you have shot a real weapon. Also I've noticed people in the reviews complaining about the utter randomness in the game including enemies, bullets, gun you get and so forth but there's a very good reason for this and I see what the developer did here.

One of the first things that you're taught when instructed in shooting is how to check your chamber. It's important to learn because it's one of the main things you do to check if your weapon is safe or not and stops you from accidentally wasting a round. You also need to check a magazine in any gun regardless of whether or not anything is chambered. Basically it's random so you get into the routine of checking your weapon like you would in real life and it's an awesome way of pounding procedure into people's heads.

On another note you can also do a trick wherein you chamber a round, take the magazine out, then put another one in to get an extra one. In conclusion if you're okay with not having the actual feeling of the shot and getting to feel that pleasurable click of loading rounds and magazine insertion it's probably worth playing if you can get it cheaply. reviewText:
If you want the short n' quick of my review, here it is: It's an incredibly challenging game with an extremely well-made gun mechanic and great immersion, but it's poorly optimized and variety is limited.

When I first picked up this game I had no idea what I was doing, and I think I quite enjoyed that at first, the first few deaths were absolutely laughable as I fumbled around with the controls manually looking up which button does what every time I needed to load another bullet or try to pick up a tape. The first thing you notice are that the graphics are mediocre at best, but in a game like this it really doesn't hurt the immersion factor one bit. The immersion is amazing, by the way. This game is an unintentional survival horror game. Enemies can and WILL scare the ♥♥♥♥ outta you.

But then after a little while I got a hang of the controls, and that's where things really picked up. After you start to get proficient at controlling the gun and even the more advanced mechanics of switching out whole mags quickly instead of just reloading a few bullets, the game gets immensely more involved. You're no longer concerned with just getting one or two tapes, you want them all. You want them bad, you've already spent several hours on this thing... So you start to learn the very well-implemented mechanics of localized damaging, where you need to hit a specific part of an enemy to take it out, and with as few bullets as possible. No CoD-style shooting at someones hands or legs to damage them.

The voice acting is not great, he fumbles around with words a bit and sometimes the sound clips a bit, but it doesn't matter because given the story it's totally reasonable for this. Story-wise: They might not have had enough time to record a super-fancy nice message. Development wise, they only had a week. Cut em' some slack.

Eventually, you get to the point where you've heard every tape a dozen times and seen every enemy almost every time, and you still may not have beaten the game because there are so many ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ tapes. At this point, there's a very real possibility that you could get tired of the game due to the lack of variety and extreme difficulty. But, if you persevere, and there's a good chance that you'll beat it, and oh boy... When you beat it, it's so satisfying. INCREDIBLY satisfying.

On top of all that there's actually a good bit of replay value thanks to the randomization of all the maps (Though it admittedly can ♥♥♥♥ you up someimtes and it's entirely possible to have an impossible-to-beat map) and even the modding community that has managed to add in a bunch of different stuff to make the game play better.

So to recap!

Pros:
+ Great gun mechanics
+ Accurate gun and bullet physics
+ Randomization of structures item locations
+ Reasonable learning curve
+ Amazing immersion
+ Very satisfying to finally beat
+ Good replay value
+ Great modding community

Cons:
- Very poor textures even on highest settings
- Poor optimization due to engine limitations
- Only 2 gun types by default
- Only 2 types of enemies
- Borderline extreme difficulty to get all 11 tapes (At least for me),
meaning it can take a long time to beat with a lot of potential frustration.
- Randomization can ♥♥♥♥ you over

Overall I would definitely recommend this game. It's an impressive and fun to play twist on the FPS genre made in only a week.

reviewText:
Receiver is not a game that everyone will like. It takes the FPS genre to a much higher level of realism. It has no difficulty settings, checkpoints, game save or HUD for that matter.
You start the game in a random room inside of a building. You don´t know who you are or why you´re there. Equipped with a 1 of 3 diferent firearms (a Glock 18, a Revolver or a 1911 45. cal Pistol), a flashlight(that you may not get on spawn but be able to find later), and nothing else than that you must find out what is going on.
When walking around the building you will find  turrets or flying robots that will try to kill you. You can fight or run, but in some areas you will just have to go trough them to progress.
You will eventually find orange sound tapes that will tell you why you´re there, how to get out, and how to effectively fight the robots and turrets. In order to finish the game you must find all 11 tapes scattered around the building.

The game mechanics will be hard to understand at 1st, but in time you will get better at it. And if you don´t like some of the controls you can change them from the Launch Menu.
You don´t have sights in the screen so you must aim to shoot properly, there are many commands for what you can do with your weapon, and the reload process must be done manually.
Ammo is in pretty short supply, so you got to look around in the building and find bullets, equip it in your magazine (or barrel) and put in your inventory(in case you are using a pistol), then have it ready to reload in combat.

Also this game is made with the Unity engine, so don´t expect anything fancy here.

reviewText:
Receiver is a very small game, and, in terms of the presentation, does feel a bit unfinished. This is understandable considering the very short dev. time, but it bears mentioning. For the most part, though, it's a very interesting game. Weapons handling is modeled in a way that no other game (that I'm aware of) has done. Instead of having a reload key, for example, the game has separate buttons to remove/insert magazines, pull the weapon's slide, pull back the hammer, etc. Once you get the hang of it, it makes for a really interesting, tactical experience using the game's weapons.

The game has a storyline told by finding 11 cassette tapes scattered around an environment that's randomly generated each time you play. Finding all 11 tapes requires a fair bit of exploration, and the random elements of the game give it decent replay-ability, even with only a few weapons and enemy types.

Overall it's an engaging, atmospheric game, but I wouldn’t recommend spending $5 on it. In fact I wouldn’t recommend spending any amount of money on it. The controls are as confusing as ♥♥♥♥, and you die very easily, almost impossible without mods. DONT BUY THIS GAME, BUY SOMETHING ELSE; THAT’S WORTH THE MONEY! I rate this at a 2/10.

if youre into gun porn and rogue-lite gameplay, Receiver is a very fun few hours.

The main fun of this game is committing the controls to memory and becoming a speedy gun nut. I've had a few moments that were generally tense or made me jump as well, due to your characters inability to take a single bullet and survive.

If you search for it, Receiver has a cool meta story that is revealed by listening to the tapes you collecting while dodging flying tazer drones and turrets.

I would definitely recommend receiver at any price, especially since the proceeds go to a small indie team that made the game in 7 days. They are also currently developing Overgrowth.

reviewText:
Receiver's main selling point is the incredibly sophisticated firearm modelling - you can interact with most of the important bits on your handgun: safety, slide, slide lock, magazine, hammer, cylinder, down to manually inserting rounds. The detail extends to the physics engine itself, with accurate balistics, and even the enemy turrets and hoverbots, which can be partially or completely disabled depending on the area they were shot in.

At first, the controls will feel quite clunky, almost like the QWOP equivalent of shooters (which was a design intention on behalf of the developers), but eventually you develop a routine for prepping your weapon. Then the game messes up your routine in panicking moments, as a hoverbot BEEPS and rushes to taze you to death.

It's a game made in 7 days, so there's bound to be several glitches and optimisation issues, but if you can look past those it's an enjoyable experience, also doubling as a way to learn a thing or two about weapons in general.

reviewText: pure gold, only thing to make this game better would be multiplayer

reviewText:
Highly visceral and deep gun handling and creepy distopian vibe are the two primary positive elements that this game has to offer. Nothing beats the feeling of learning the gun mechanics and successfully using them against the (sadly) 2 types of enemies you'll face during the game.

The map is randomly generated for each playthrough and each time you die but things will definitely start to look familiar the more you play. Your mission is to locate 11 tapes that are scattered around the map and listen to their dialogue while staying alive. Be very careful while turning each corner in this game because a single enemy shot will kill you and send you back to the beginning. Oh and did I mention the guns are also randomized? There are 3 guns total but how many bullets they have and whether they're loaded, cocked or with the safety on can vary between each start.

On the negative side, there are framerate hitches whenever you walk into new areas and the levels can get really dark. The flashlight proved more of a nuisance than help because it only lights up a few feet in front of you. This could mean life or death in this game. There are no gamma settings in the game. Also, as I mentioned previously, the levels can get a bit repetitive at times because they are seemingly different pre-made areas which are stitched together in different ways because of the level generator.

All in all, a very entertaining game. Definitely get this on a sale. The adrenaline rush and realistic gun handling are definitely worth quite a few hours of random fun.

reviewText:
This game is very crafty and all of the spawns, from rooms to what you spawn with, are randomized. The game very quickly teaches you to be cautious, ranging from punishing you for running into a room without looking into it first, to immediately being rammed in the side with a drone with no way to counter against it.

How enemies spawn is randomized, and sometimes a bunch of turrets will be spawned in such a way that you'll need to tactfully take out each one before you can move on, and sometimes it'll cluster 5 turrets in one room.

To keep you on your toes, how quickly you can react to turrets seeing you varies, ranging from being able to be seen by a turret for a full second and not die, to being shot the instant you enter their field of vision.

Additionally, it seems how durable the robots are is also randomized. For example, sometime's you'll take out 4 enemies with one shot each, and sometimes you'll have to dump 10 bullets into a turret's weakpoint before it stops moving.

What you spawn with is randomized, which means sometimes you can spawn with a revolver and 30 bullets, and sometimes you'll spawn with a M1911A1 and 4 bullets.

Where you spawn is also randomized. Sometimes you'll spawn in a room full of ammo and maybe a tape and/or flashlight, and sometimes you'll spawn in direct view of a turret.

Don't get me wrong, this is a great game, it's just that if you're purchasing this, prepare for RNGesus to kick you in the butt. A lot.

reviewText:
Created for the 7-day FPS challenge?
That's cute.
Publish and do no update to improve your game?
Ha, ha, no.

-------------------------

Let's start with system requirements.
- Can you run smoothly with just 2.0 GHz CPU?
No.

- Can you run smoothly with just 2 GB RAM?
No way on earth possible after traveling 5 new zones.

- Then why doesn't the developer team change it?
They never bother to optimize their game. They let the community to do it for them.

Side note: The only time I can accept poorly optimized game if the developer team has attempted to update in good faith but no longer exist. (i.e. Vampire the Masquerade Bloodlines)

-------------------------

Ok, let's say you can run this game and play it.

- What is that? No spare magazine for your 1911?
Better restart.

- What is that? No tape (The objective to pick up 11 tapes in game) in next room?
Better restart.

- Not your favorite gun?
Better restart.

- No bullet / only one or two bullets at the start?
Better hope no enemy behind the corner.
Oh wait, what am I saying.
BETTER RESTART.

- Five flying drones in a room?
Better U-turn now.
If not possible, BETTER RESTART.

I understand this is rogue-like, but not having a spare empty magazine and some bullets at the start is asking players to restart endlessly.

------------------------

Now, gun handling mechanics.
This is only interesting mechanic in this game.

- Want to know how to load bullets into magazine like in real life?
Sure.

- Want to know reload your gun?
Sure.

- Want to know the steps to fire your gun?
Sure.

While gun handling mechanics are great,
Cons > Pros

------------------------

TL;DR
This is one of those games that the developer team decided to publish their game and do nothing to improve it.
Wait on sale if you want to try gun handling mechanics.
For other reasons, No.

reviewText:
I like the idea of it. I like the idea of a game where you actually have to go through all the motions of maintaining your weapon, e.g. opening the chamber, extracting the empty casings, loading the new bullets, closing the chamber, pulling the hammer, etc. There is something tactile about it that is very satisfying.

The thing that really kills it for me, though, is that the different styles of gun lead to completely different control schemes. Sometimes equipping the flashlight is the 2 key, but sometimes it is the 1 key. In one round, tapping Z causes you to load more bullets into the empty chambers you're examining, but in the next round, pressing Z will make you drop the clip you're examining onto the ground (even if it's full). There are too many buttons doing too many things as it is, but then when the game shifts them around on you every round, it only compounds the problem. Those who are patient enough to go through the pain of memorizing all this may not have a bad time, but it is a major hurdle to the enjoyment of the game.

The point at which I quit the game though was when I loaded a new round and the randomization placed me inside a room with a flying turret directly behind me. Literally, the round started, I heard a gunshot, and the round was over. I know roguelikes are super into busting the player's balls with randomization, but that seemed a bit steep.

In short, I love the idea, but I don't think I like the execution.

reviewText:
As a gun nut from Indiana I really wanted to love this game. I can't remember how I ended up getting it on Steam--I had it before I had a Steam account and I didn't like it then either. But I decided after reinstalling it that I would try playing it to see if I could get good at it.

It was made in like 24 hours so it's perfectly excusable that I can't recommend it. But things like rendering shouldn't be a problem for most players of a game. I don't have much trouble with other, more complex games with textures and stuff that my computer actually has to load as it goes. Unless I reduce the resolution to like 560x480 or something ludicrously tiny like that, this game is completely unplayable because of the lag (a common complaint, it seems).

Aside from that, this game is not intuitive in the slightest. It looks like I'm definitely not the only person who has had incredible amounts of trouble just figuring out how to load my handgun. Again, this is excusable because it was made in so little time. If you're a diehard fan of guns and roguelikes, have uncanny powers of patience and fantastic eyesight, maybe watch a trailer or something and see if you think you would like it. Personally, I would not pay anything for a sequel unless it was a fully-developed and crafted game.

reviewText:
I can't really recommend Receiver for the price of $5.00. The storyline is short and not compelling, the game doesn't run or look particularly well at all, and the gunplay is unique, but not enough to hold my interest.

The story is told through audiotapes found randomly throughout the game. I found it rather uninteresting, which in part is to be expected as the primary objective of the developer was to experiment with gunplay mechanics. As a result we have a storyline that just gives you a reason to collect audiotapes and shoot guns at robots.

The game did not run particularly well for me, and I doubt it’s a problem with my hardware. Clipping and pop-ins are fairly common. The environment is not textured so anything other than the guns you use look bland. The backdrop of a metropolis was a nice touch but overall the game was unimpressive graphically and technically.

The gameplay is centered on the gunplay. You are given a random gun in a random condition with a random amount of ammo. You can manipulate nearly any aspect of the gun including pulling the hammer back or loading bullets individually into a magazine, and each action requires a different key. It takes time to learn, but once you start to figure it out it becomes increasingly satisfying to quickly empty the casings out of a revolver and reload it. You fight two types of enemies, a flying taser robot and a turret. Different parts of the enemies react in different ways when shot, so accuracy is rewarded over speed. For example the strategy I usually attempted to employ was to shoot the camera on the turrets as ideally it would take one bullet, and they would no longer be able to detect me. Admittedly the gunplay is interesting, but in the end I don't think it’s capable of holding up the whole package.

Without a worthwhile story and weak graphics, the gameplay fails to make this game worth the $5.00 price tag. I'm glad someone experimented with gunplay to make this game, and if you can pick it up for a cheaper price or free, it is worth trying. Gun enthusiasts should also reconsider what I have said, because this game might be something you will find quite enjoyable.

reviewText:
This game is an interesting concept piece, but falls utterly flat on it's face. Everything about the game is in need of polish, from an awful UI (for such an extremely sparse UI as it is), to intentionally poor control layout, to the combination of these factors exacerbating its brutal difficulty. It's impressive how such a simple game can fail on so many levels.

The game is brutal in it's difficulty. Not because the enemies can kill you with a single hit, or that they greatly outnumber you, or that you have very limited ammo, or that it's intentionally difficult to aim your weapon properly, or that some enemies appear to be able to absorb prodigious amounts of ammo for little to no good reason. No, the biggest difficulty creator is the fact that there is no rhyme or reason to the control layout beyond the normal movement and aiming and firing controls. Yes, the game is supposed to have a difficult mechanic of maintaining your weapon. But the button placements make no sense - they neither emulate the firearm that you are using, nor are they set up in a way that encourages a logical pattern. They're just generally clustered around the WASD keys like the developer just slapped them down whenever he thought of a new feature that guns have that he had yet to implement.

The only hook into the plot (what little plot there appears be) is from audio tapes that have a poor voice over that you may or may not find near the beginning of your adventure. There is nothing that will make you feel like you have a need to complete the plot, other than any intrinsic desire you may still harbor for completing the game for the sake of completion alone.

Also, a very special frustration that I managed to encounter is the fact that the game offers no way to reset one's controls to the defaults, but the UI that gives you control hints entirely works on having the default controls. So if you change your controls you'll either need to give up on using the tutorial UI, or find them online (at the time I write this I was incapable of finding them listed), or delete your registry keys from Windows so the game is forced into returning your defaults to you.

The only people who should buy this game are the heedlessly masochistic and the curious game developers who want to explore the concept and how not to approach it. Even then, wait until it's on sale.

reviewText:
WOW... major dissapointment. I really wanted to like this game, I really did, but there is a major problem with it. This game is sooooooo poorly optimized it is nearly unplayable. According to the store page, my PC not only met the Minimum requirements, but the Recommended requrements (barely but still) yet the game had UNBEARABLE framerate and mouse lag. I  mean it takes almost 2 seconds for the gun to move after you move the mouse. Sure, what's 2 seconds? Well in a game where you have enemies that are flying quickly, turrets that can kill you almost immediately after spotting you and limited ammo to hit small targets on previously stated enemies... yeah the mouse lag can really be a problem. It wouldn't bother me if the requirements of my PC aren't powerful enough, but I have read the requirements and they match (so don't blame my crappy Computer that [supposedly] meets the requirements).

Now onto the actual game... there isn't much. The game is very simple. Collect all the Cassette Tapes around the level, while killing off all enemies and trying to survive. The main feature is the realistic gun unloading/reloading mechanics. Everytime you need to reload or whatever, you need to manually pull back slide, take out magazine, store in inventory, take new magazine out of inventory, load new magazine, unlock slide, and pull back hammer before being able to fire your gun. Each step has its own corresponding key to hit and it overall is annoying. It loses its novelty very quickly and just makes reloading a chore. It also makes it impossible in a firefight. Also each of the three different weapons has different reloading sequences... great.

Also levels are randomly generated after death. So once you die, cassete location, enemy location and type, bullet count, flashlight batterey life, and gun type all change. This gives the challenge and overall is annoying since enemies (who instakill I should add) can be right around any corner. Also bullets are in random spots so good luck finding them when you have ran out and are now running from your life against flying guys in a hallway that has a turret around the corner at the end of it. What should happen is instead of the levels randomize after death, have a randomize button so you can know the layout and actually finish a level.

Overall, the game has a cool idea but the poor optimization and annoying instakill enemies with tiny weakpoints ruin a game that could have had some really tense atmosphere.

reviewText: Although the unique gameplay concept (surviving with a barely-loaded and mechanically simulated gun in a mysterious roguelike world) is laudable, little else about Receiver is; the optimization is shockingly poor even on high-end machines, the game has zero polish, and the gameplay ends up being more finicky trial-and-error than challenging fun.\n\nExcellent for having been created in a week, but not really a marketable game in its current state--think of this as an Early Access title with no updates in the near-future pipeline. Buy on sale if you're really curious (that's what I did) or skip.

reviewText: While the gun handling is really good, everything else is iffy to bad. The story in the tapes you collect ingame is mildly interesting, but not great. There's very little music, and it's nothing special. The level is really basic, boring, and overly minimalistic. Visuals are generally kinda ugly, without much style too. There's only two types of enemies, and while the idea of hitting them in specific locations is a cool idea, it's really tough in practice. The turrets aren't too hard to hit (there's a bit of a challenge, but not too much) or in some cases just to avoid, but the flying drones are nearly impossible to hit in the critical spots, and can require more than one hit, despite them flying extremely erratically. Combat can be frustrating, and not in a way that made me feel skilled for dispatching an enemy, so much as glad I wasn't hit myself. After almost two hours of trying to enjoy this game, I realized my hope was futile. The idea and core gunplay of a game is there, but nothing else of substance. Oh! I almost forgot the worst offence! It's buggy and laggy to high hell! I thought it might have just been my so-so laptop I had played it on, but numerous other reviewers had the same issues. 3.5/10 could have been something cool (and lag free) if the devs spent more time on it.

reviewText: I thought about writing a positive review for this game, but then I realized I was going off half-cocked. Now, I'm not exactly gun-shy, but I think I really shot myself in the foot after shelling out 5 dollars for this.\n\nNow, let me put a bead on the issue--This game had me chewing the rag for a bit. It didn't exactly feel as if the developers had kept their powder dry.  I fell for the gun-lover niche" lock
recommended: and barrel. I actually enjoyed the game for a bit--but then I realized the experience was just a flash in the pan. The game wasn't exactly loaded for bear--its arsenal wasn't the most varied. I'm not just shooting blanks here--there are only 3 guns in this game that absolutely focuses on firearm-realism. I know the developers made this in 7 days
hoursPlayed: but it feels like they went off on a hair-trigger.\n\nTL;DR meme game get it on sale for 3.99 or less."

reviewText: Receiver is an excellent panic simulator. Initially, you'll be confused by the profusion of controls, but with practice, it gets easier. It never gets to the point of feeling invincible; you're always a single mistake away from death. This game is utterly without mercy, and you will inevitably die a lot. You'll get very bored with the tapes, too.\n\nReceiver may be merciless, but it is fair. Your enemies are just as fragile as you are. With practice, you'll take them down easily - as long as you're cautious. For what it is, a procedural death labyrinth, Receiver is an interesting exploration of shooting mechanics.

reviewText:
Receiver is a First Person Shooter about guns. Like, really about guns. The main attraction of this game is how it handles gunplay so realistically. Rather than have you automatically reload, you have to manually do each step to reload. If you miss up, there's just more time for flying sentries or turrets to get you. The point of the game is to traverse a randomly generated maze of bleak colors to find cassette tapes that provide background to the universe.

The game's atmosphere is wonderfully dark and creepy. It does a great job of making you feel alone, and the dark colors combined with the low-quality models and textures create a sense of dread and otherness that makes you really feel like you're out of your element, running through a maze you have no map of that's filled with enemies that are more location-savvy than you.

The gameplay is fun and rewarding. When you first start, you're probably gonna be really slow at handling your gun. You'll die a lot, and you'll forget certain steps, completely halting any progress in loading a new magazine into your weapon, typically under enemy fire. You won't have much ammo, and will have to conserve your bullets, though eventually you will run out right before entering a room full of enemies. As you get better at the game, you'll be able to load your gun faster and be more precise with your shots, wasting less ammo. This game does a good job of making you feel like you are progressing at the game because it is solely skill-based.

I'd buy it.

reviewText: I love this game. For being made in a single week, and only having ONE content update, this game manages to create so much tension, and feeling, and amazing, it could put some big-name games to shame. And the mechanics are super fun to learn and use. Randomized level generation keeps things interesting, and the one hit death keeps a certain tension in the air that keeps you on your toes. The only two issues I have are as follows; no sprinting, and performance. No sprinting simply because if you happen to be crossing a large room or bridge with nothing around, navigation can be tedious. The performance thing is only an issue if you play full-screened. Just keep it in a window, with the appropriate level of detail, and you should be able to run it just fine.

reviewText:
Okay, so we have a lot of keys to remember, and the guns act a LITTLE more like real firearms, but this isn't even really a game.  There is no presented objective, and you are fighting little helicopter drone things that just appear and zap you.
Waste of time, really.  If you want realistic gun action, just go out to the range and fire off a few.
The controls are FAR from intuitive, there is NO tutorial, and you cannot view or rebind keys in-game.  The FOV is tiny both horizontally and vertically, and the environment is boring.  The music, while indeed creating tension, is repetitive and just gets on your nerves after a couple of minutes.

Seriously, if you want realistic firearms action, just get a cheap .22 and get out of the house, take a safety class, go to the range, and squeeze off a few.  You'll find it very different, and much more satisfying than this game.""

reviewText:
One Sentence Summary - If you like pressing 15 buttons to shoot a gun, buy this game... otherwise, buy something else...

--REVIEW--
I simply cannot say that I recommend this game. It seems that this game was more of a tech demo than anything. Other than the Tron" sounding background music
date: this game really doesn't provide any emotional connection with the player. The game simply starts... there is no story provided
recommended: other than the players having some sort of idea that they are running along some rooftops looking for cassette tapes. I assume these tapes give some sort of minimalistic story. I get the point that this was made for some 7-day FPS challenge
hoursPlayed: but they could have at least given the player some sort of story or motivation to find these tapes. The graphics are incredibly minimalistic
voteText: yet it runs poorly on my laptop
helpfulPercent: even on the "fastest" setting. I get much better performance playing something like Dragon Age or FInal Fantasy 13 than I would on this game. When I turned the resolution down to the lowest setting (like 600x800 or so)
votesHelpful: I got decent performance. You might as well do this
votesTotal:
because you won't lose any graphical details... because there are none to lose. I believe this to be either a hardware compatability problem or simply not programmed well to run efficiently.

---PROS---
+Minimalistic/Non-existent story (if you like that sort of thing)
+Tron music
+Very "realistic" process of having to load and reload a gun.

---CONS---
-Minimalistic/Non-existent story
-No Tron motorcycles or discs
-You have to press way too many buttons to load a gun. There is no tutorial or simple explanation other than pressing the "?" button for help
votesFunny:
and blindly pressing the buttons until your gun is ready to shoot.
-Graphics are very minimalistic (AKA- Didn't have time to add detail)
-The game runs extremely poor on a dual core laptop with 8GB ram.
-For the average game player
commentsCount:
I think the gun loading process is extremely cumbersome... At least make a tutorial or arrange the buttons in a streamlined order.

---CONCLUSION---
If you like randomly generated worlds in games with no story
column16: as well as tron music and hard to load guns
column17: this is the game for you. For the rest of us
column18: we'll be better off playing something else."

reviewText: The music sets the atmosphere just right and the gunplay feels tight with all the mechanics working in unison. Ironsights are dead on and allow you to pull off the shot you want every single time. The guns all have their specific strengths and weaknesses, and add a new layer of depth to every playthrough, without feeling like one or another is OP in any way. Enemies are interesting and require strategic thinking to overcome. The difficulty level adds to the suspense of the game, and the will to try harder and collect more tapes on every try keeps the user coming back.\n\nSolid game.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: It's hard to explain, it's kind of a FPS adventure game. You explore randomly genned buildings to find 10 recordings. It has some really interesting and detailed gun mechanics and provides a huge challenge. The enemies consist of turrets and these flying patrol bots. The turrets are easy to take out but you have to be careful not to rush into a room, they'll kill you right away if you're spotted. The patrol bots are the big issue, they're difficult to hit in mid air and they move very very fast. A big part of the game is luck and exploring, you'll need to get a lucky world gen and if you're not so lucky you'll have to go looking for bullets and hopefully find a revolver. It's pretty simple and might bore some people. But I suggest checking out some gameplay videos. It's pretty original and can provide some enjoyment. 7.9/10.

reviewText:
More of a tech demo than a game. But the basic gameplay elements, controls, are rarely if never before seen. I have not encountered a game that makes you actually manipulate a firearm in the ways this game makes you. You are forced to load a magazine manually, load the mag into the gun, turn the safety off, rack the slide, then you can commence the shooting. Which is unweildy and hard to remember during high stress situations just like with real guns.

Its a shame the gameplay is crap and it runs so poorly on my machine. Framerate bogs down for no reason for me and the enemys that fly are often going to kill you out of nowhere. Its all randomly generated, but more often than not those flying ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s will be in a ridiculous spot that its either easy to shoot them or you are dead before you could even know you were being attacked.

That said these elements need to be taken and put into a survival horror game. Chance the controls for firearm manipulation to the mouse maybe or not, this game needs to be made.

But unless you really like to see diffrent games and this game" is on sale than don't buy it. Its not worth the price they have asked for it because its very very basic to the point of being a demo of gameplay for a much larger game. A larger game that dousn't exist."

reviewText: Some times you start with a flashlight. Sometimes you don't. Sometimes you have a lot of ammo, sometimes you don't. This game in its own way is one of the most immersive and impressive FPS ever to be made. Each of the 3 firearms has its own quirks such as having to manually eject the shells wit the revolver or the Colt M1911A1 that on ocassion is given to you uncocked or with the saftey on. Most of the time you realise that when a drone s flying at your head :P. Definatley worth the 4 quid you pay for. But be warned patience is required for learning the mechanics. Enjoy!

reviewText: Pretty difficult to run with a reasonable framerate (I'm currently doing so by playing with a lower resolution), but it's definitely worth it. The gun mechanics are a massive breath of fresh air, the story is really compelling, and the atmosphere is just ridiculously tense. I have no problem with admitting that I'm afraid of the dark, but that normally doesn't affect me in games. However, Receiver somehow manages to hit the part of my brain that real darkness does. Truly a phenomenal piece.

reviewText:
For a game made in a week, it's pretty great. It's inherently satisfying to manually reload your weapon as quickly as you can, once you have a grasp on the mechanics. It's tense and fun when you hear a drone around a corner, look out for its camera light, and time it just right to shoot and disable it unscathed. There's some nice use of adaptive music, a scarcity of ammunition forcing you to make every shot count, and some terrifying flying drones to escape from.

However, being made in a short amount of time, in Unity, and using randomly generated environments, I've run into framerate issues, repetitive environments, graphical whoopsies, and situations with no chance of success. As well, the objective of collecting tapes involves listening to a monotone voice drone exposition that is often heard over and over again after respawning. You can fully mute the voice volume in the settings, at least.

It's worth the $5 pricetag, but I was happy to pick it up on sale if you catch my drift.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is the proof that you don't need Michael Bay level graphics to make an excellent game.

The atmosphere in the game is pretty intense and keeps you on the edge of your seat. Complex gun mechanics are a really nice addition to the gaming world, despite all the keys you need to make them work (I keep the keys info always in the side of the screen!).

Randomized levels help re-playability and it's needed because you're going to die a lot.

reviewText:
Warning:
This is not a complete game, consider this a tech demo since this game was done in a week!

Now that we got that out of the way, onto the game.
Receiver is a first person shooter rogue-like.
Everytime you spawn, you get a random weapon with a random inventory on a randomly generated world.
The objective is simple, obtain 11 tapes around the map and you win. But it's not that easy. There are enemies scattered around the world and it is your choice to either bypass them or shoot your way through. Remember, your health is a 1 shot kill. So you only get 1 chance.
The main core of the gameplay in this game is the guns. Unlike normal shooters, youl have to input various keys to perform actions in your guns. Reloading can take 4 keys to press. The ballistics include bullet drop and ricochet.
While the gun mechanics are pretty realistic, the enemies have a pretty estratigic way to deal with them apart from just shooting them.
While there are only 2 types of enemies, they are enough to make you pull your hair out. Enemies are pretty much sentries and drones. And they must function somehow. The strategy to eliminate enemies is to shoot vital parts. For example, you can shoot the sensor and they won't spot you anymore. Il leave the rest for you to find out the other vital parts. If you so desire to get the game of course.

But lets review the features of this game.
Features

Detailed simulations of a Colt 1911 pistol, S&W Model 10 Victory" revolver
date: and Glock 17 with full-auto mod\nWhile partially true
recommended:
the guns do have detailed models and ways to operate them. But they mostly include only the important bits of the gun for the gameplay.

Taser robots and machine gun turrets with physically-based damage models
As said above before the features. This is true.

Ballistic modeling of ricochets and bullet drop
Again
hoursPlayed: as said above
voteText:
this is true. Nothing else to had.

11 audio tapes to prepare you to defend yourself against the inevitable Mindkill event
The tapes are the objective of the game
helpfulPercent: these tapes explain the world you live in
votesHelpful: the guns and how to use them
votesTotal: the machines and how they work etc. They also include parts of the story. I find this a very interesting way to have a tutorial. But it's not a very good way to deliver one. The audio tapes are random
votesFunny: so the chances of you getting a tape explaining how the enemies work
commentsCount:
can take sometime.

Become literate in how guns actually operate
I can confirm this since I shot the floor
column16: the bullet ricochet and still killed me. Don't shoot the floor kids.\n\nWhile the game can be fun and frustrating at times
column17:
it delivers quite an experience no other game can achieve.
I belive it took me 9 hours to finally complete the game once.

Now for the moment of truth. Buy or not to buy?
For 5 bucks

reviewText:
Receiver is one of those rare games that feels entirely new and fresh.
While it is your standard survival-adventure shooter in terms of action, it is so much more than that. Receiver is one of those rare games that actually makes you work to succeed. You have to memorize the steps to get your gun working or you will die quickly and repeatedly, you have to learn your enemy's weak spots, you have to learn how to safely enter a room or hallway. Receiver is near impossible difficulty, but I always find myself picking it back up.
It's not a game about completion, but rather a game about mechanics. The guns feel good, the game has occasionaly jarring (but generally good) progression.
You'd be daft to not get this game when it's on sale.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Receiver is a very interesting little experiment that bases its gameplay around the mechanic that you have to manually reload your weapon like a puzzle, essentially a on the fly FPS puzzel game.

It doesn't take too long to figure out how to properly reload everything and very soon you will be reloading faster than ever, so in the end it becomes a interesting little survival game to keep you distracted.

I honestly wish this game would continue to be updated because there is a huge realm of possibilities to add in terms of weapons that could be used. Like shotguns, crossbows, bolt action rifles, all of these things would bring fantastic variety to this game, adding onto the list of different weapons you need to remember how to reload in different ways.

But alas, it remains as it is, with only 3 weapons to use and toy with. Although the product itself is good, it's a shame when you imagine all that it could of had.

reviewText: For such a simplistic game, it should take only about 1.5-1.7 GHz to play this. But no. It lags like crazy even if you have a medium PC. Think about this. Skyrim, the massive open-world, plays fine on my 1.7 GHz laptop at 30fps to 60fps at medium settings. This game, plays about 10fps constantly. I can tell they didn't care about this game because the graphics are terrible and they didn't even take time to optimize it. There is some stuff good about it like the combat and use of atmosphere to give you an alone feeling and other stuff but I'd say that it isn't really worth the £4 that it sells for. Maybe £1. Overall, I believe its a like it or hate it game.

reviewText: Reciever is worth looking at if only for the way it handles its pistols in a much more mechanical, realistic fashion than most other FPS's. Unfortunately, that's the only thing it has going for it. It's an interesting concept that is trapped in a half-baked, Slendermanish shell. Random weapon loadout, random level design, search for the mcguffin objectives (with embarassing voice work), and frustrating enemies that have locational damage models that mean that it's pretty much random if your shots do any good.\n\nBasically, the game is designed as youtube scarecam fodder, with all that entails. As a proof of concept, it does a magnifcent job in demonstrating more immersive gun mechanics. As a game, it gets old really fast.

reviewText:
Pros:
-Realistic firearms simulation. It feels like you actually control the gun
-Interesting story
-Quite a lot of stuff put into it, considering it was made in seven days

Cons:
-Takes more processing power than all of my other games. I have a decent computer and even on the fastest setting it was slow. I tried it on my other computers to the same effect. This caused my character to jerk around unpredictably and made it hard to aim my gun; I died frequently.
-Graphics are from 1998
-I kept encountering this glitch where the gun shakes back and forth rapidly and when I fire the gun I shoot myself instead.
-Gun mechanics are frustrating at first, with a lot of buttons to memorize.
-Randomized, sometimes requires lots of moving back and forth and can be frustrating.

Go for it, but make sure you have a powerful PC first.

reviewText: It's not a good game BUT that's not what you should buy it for (when it's discounted). It's about the gun handling. Once you have gotten the hang of it and played a while, you'll want mechanics like these in other games, too.\n\nTip, which might not work for everybody, but it worked well for me: Change the keyboard configuration. The game's built-in help will still show the old keys :( but the names of the functions listed in the external window where you reassign the keys, those will tell you just what you need to know, and when you have reassigned those functions, you'll kinda know what to do when. It's actually pretty easy. The in-game help can be a little confusing, so ignore it. Just reassign the keys and study the existing functions in the process.

reviewText: Been playing this game here and there for a while now. This game is pretty nice in a lot of concepts. For example, how you control your gun. There are 3 basic weapons; The M1911 Colt, the Glock 18, and a .357 Revolver (I think it is a .357) and all three have their own way of control. The Colt and Glock have the same controls except that hitting V forthe Colt will put on the Safety while the Glock makes it either go Semi or Automatic. I like the Revolver and how you can spin the chamber as much as you want with the mouse wheel. Or you can spin it before you place it back. There is a lot of stuff about the game that makes it a good game. On the other hand, I do go through a little bit of some issues here and there. For example, I get random FPS drops when going through different areas on the map, but it goes away half a second later. And I am currently having Lighting FX issues (Probably my side). Besides that, this game is definitely worth it. Especially with the recent gun additions to the game.\n\n9/10

reviewText: From what I have played so far, the game is fun, but very very challenging at first. I am starting to get some of the gun mechanics now, and things are getting a little easier. Definitely a very different experience than many shooter actiony type games I have played. I have some issues with framerate due to the dynamic lighting. This game is probably one of those games which you play every now and then at the very least. It might be a bit too frustrating for the new player to develop a vested interest in.\n-------------------------------------------------------------UPDATED-------------------------------------------------------------------------\nIf you get the mod that can be found somewhere, just look around or ask for it on the community hub, it will improve framerate and add new guns including a shotgun, bolt action rifle, and tommy gun, as well as one or two others. These guns add more depth to the game, operating a bit differently than the ones the game comes with. The framerate boost is extremely helpful. With the mod the player can get a lot more out of this game. Good job to whoever made it.

reviewText:
Warning:
This is not a complete game, consider this a tech demo since this game was done in a week!

Now that we got that out of the way, onto the game.
Receiver is a first person shooter rogue-like.
Everytime you spawn, you get a random weapon with a random inventory on a randomly generated world.
The objective is simple, obtain 11 tapes around the map and you win. But it's not that easy. There are enemies scattered around the world and it is your choice to either bypass them or shoot your way through. Remember, your health is a 1 shot kill. So you only get 1 chance.
The main core of the gameplay in this game is the guns. Unlike normal shooters, youl have to input various keys to perform actions in your guns. Reloading can take 4 keys to press. The ballistics include bullet drop and ricochet.
While the gun mechanics are pretty realistic, the enemies have a pretty estratigic way to deal with them apart from just shooting them.
While there are only 2 types of enemies, they are enough to make you pull your hair out. Enemies are pretty much sentries and drones. And they must function somehow. The strategy to eliminate enemies is to shoot vital parts. For example, you can shoot the sensor and they won't spot you anymore. Il leave the rest for you to find out the other vital parts. If you so desire to get the game of course.

But lets review the features of this game.
Features

Detailed simulations of a Colt 1911 pistol, S&W Model 10 Victory" revolver
date: and Glock 17 with full-auto mod\nWhile partially true
recommended:
the guns do have detailed models and ways to operate them. But they mostly include only the important bits of the gun for the gameplay.

Taser robots and machine gun turrets with physically-based damage models
As said above before the features. This is true.

Ballistic modeling of ricochets and bullet drop
Again
hoursPlayed: as said above
voteText:
this is true. Nothing else to had.

11 audio tapes to prepare you to defend yourself against the inevitable Mindkill event
The tapes are the objective of the game

votesTotal: the machines and how they work etc. They also include parts of the story. I find this a very interesting way to have a tutorial. But it's not a very good way to deliver one. The audio tapes are random

can take sometime.

Become literate in how guns actually operate
I can confirm this since I shot the floor

it delivers quite an experience no other game can achieve.
I belive it took me 9 hours to finally complete the game once.

Now for the moment of truth. Buy or not to buy?
For 5 bucks

reviewText:
Receiver is one of those rare games that feels entirely new and fresh.
While it is your standard survival-adventure shooter in terms of action, it is so much more than that. Receiver is one of those rare games that actually makes you work to succeed. You have to memorize the steps to get your gun working or you will die quickly and repeatedly, you have to learn your enemy's weak spots, you have to learn how to safely enter a room or hallway. Receiver is near impossible difficulty, but I always find myself picking it back up.
It's not a game about completion, but rather a game about mechanics. The guns feel good, the game has occasionaly jarring (but generally good) progression.
You'd be daft to not get this game when it's on sale.

reviewText: It's not a good game BUT that's not what you should buy it for (when it's discounted). It's about the gun handling. Once you have gotten the hang of it and played a while, you'll want mechanics like these in other games, too.\n\nTip, which might not work for everybody, but it worked well for me: Change the keyboard configuration. The game's built-in help will still show the old keys :( but the names of the functions listed in the external window where you reassign the keys, those will tell you just what you need to know, and when you have reassigned those functions, you'll kinda know what to do when. It's actually pretty easy. The in-game help can be a little confusing, so ignore it. Just reassign the keys and study the existing functions in the process.

reviewText: Some quality gaming. The most high quality gaming I've had the pleasure to game in quite some time. To game on this game you have to press a lot of buttons, gaming that only a real gamer can game in a game. I went into this game expecting a quick gaming session, but in all my years of gaming I have never misjudged a game's gaming potential so badly. The game itself is simple to game, you are a simple gamer and the game is to find 11 game tapes for the game. You game with a gun and you find ammo, and if you game hard enough you might collect all 11 tapes. I have not gamed hard enough for such a game as this, and I have disgraced my gamer family. But I haven't heard of anybody gaming hard enough to give this game the business (game business, of course), so perhaps I will be allowed back into my game family. Quality game for any gamer to game when they feel like a casual game or a serious game this game can go either way. I'd rate this game pretty well but, being a simple gamer, I am compelled to meme.\n10/10 would game again

reviewText: Created by a team of 4 in a week for a FPS game design challenge, Receiver revolves around realistic gun mechanics in a (very) randomly generated world. Reloading magazines manually

reviewText: Once I got past that horrible voice from the Gemini Rue commentary trying his hardest to sound like Werner Herzog, Receiver revealed itself to be the most exciting and rewarding shooter I've ever played. The moment you realize you've been reloading and operating your M1911A from reflex memory, you feel giddy. And then you become just careless enough to get caught in a simple drone trap that you would've spotted if you weren't in your own head. Unlike most 5-30 minute games out there, this one has replay value because it's actually fun and you do more than just walk around. No, you don't learn about the magical power of love and ponder humanism. You shoot stuff.

reviewText: Before you chew me out for only playing an hour and a half of this game first let me tell you about it. This game is great. The idea is fantastic and the sense of survival it goes for is achieved. Does it look like it could have been made in Google SketchUp? YES (at least on my computer it does). But it goes surprisingly deep for what it is. You spawn in a random part of what appears to be a huge house, or apartment bulidings, or neither I'm really not sure. You are then given one of three handguns, a Glock, a revolver, and a Colt 1911. This is where the game get's really interesting. The controls focus around the gun. There is a key set to open the reciever, a key set to take out the magazine, a key set to pull the hammer back. Everything you would actually do with a gun, and magazine for that matter, there's a key for it in this game. To me that is fantastic. It's new to me, and I tend to doubt there have been many if any games that follow that same idea. The second interesting point of this game are the audiotapes you pick up. They give a wonderful backstory to the game, telling you why you are there, and hinting at something sinister. In that way, it's like the Matrix, only voiced by Microsoft Sam. If you see this game for 50%, heck 33% off or more buy it. You will not regret it. This game get's my 7/10. The idea is great, but I wish the game was more replayable.

reviewText: Reciever is worth looking at if only for the way it handles its pistols in a much more mechanical, realistic fashion than most other FPS's. Unfortunately, that's the only thing it has going for it. It's an interesting concept that is trapped in a half-baked, Slendermanish shell. Random weapon loadout, random level design, search for the mcguffin objectives (with embarassing voice work), and frustrating enemies that have locational damage models that mean that it's pretty much random if your shots do any good.\n\nBasically, the game is designed as youtube scarecam fodder, with all that entails. As a proof of concept, it does a magnifcent job in demonstrating more immersive gun mechanics. As a game, it gets old really fast.

reviewText: For such a simplistic game, it should take only about 1.5-1.7 GHz to play this. But no. It lags like crazy even if you have a medium PC. Think about this. Skyrim, the massive open-world, plays fine on my 1.7 GHz laptop at 30fps to 60fps at medium settings. This game, plays about 10fps constantly. I can tell they didn't care about this game because the graphics are terrible and they didn't even take time to optimize it. There is some stuff good about it like the combat and use of atmosphere to give you an alone feeling and other stuff but I'd say that it isn't really worth the £4 that it sells for. Maybe £1. Overall, I believe its a like it or hate it game.

reviewText: how to actually reload a gun and manage ammo simulator. This game is purely based on getting a good seed where you actually have a clips worth of ammo when you spawn, and that you aren't immediately swarmed by 2 turrets and 3 flying drones in the first room you walk into. Haven't beaten it yet. Graphics are crap, and everything feels awkward. But that's kind of why I love it too. It's kind of the addiction you get from playing qwop, where you barely feel in control, but with a sense of reward from collecting those tapes and those tense moments in each new room where you have no idea if a turret is going to come out of nowhere and shoot your ♥♥♥♥ off. It may be a bit sloppy, but every respawn feels fresh and it could be a while until you give up. A great game to pick up on a sale of 50% or so.\ntl;dr: it's a short and sweet game, meant to be picked up at about 2$. You get what you pay for, but odds are you'll enjoy it while it lasts.

reviewText:
Great game, great weapon mechanics, great choice of enemies (it would be mindboggling to detail soft tissue damage and bullet hit dynamics in biological enemies). The narrative is creepy, makes me feel like the reason its' so easy to die in this game and the lack of saves is so that you repeatedly have to be brainwashed by the tapes (oohh.. a conspiracy by developers :P). *Shudder*. And Hong Kong background is a bonus, creeps me out even more. Otherwise, it's quite addictive. To be honest I thought we'd have the same weapon mechanics by 2002 in games, but thanks to MS and console crowd its in an indie game in 2013.

Also, this is more Dues Ex than anything Eidos threw up in the past decade. And I see hints of Shadow Watch here as well. An exquisite game and if the developers will stay on this path despite the perverted game industry's demands, my entire respect to them. You are on the right path!

reviewText: Reciever I found to be quite a dull and repetitive game, you are placed into a weird futurestic city with the task of finding 11 cassete tapes, your simple mission. The games biggest draw is the fact that it has a very relaistic and unique gun system which although cklever I found quite annoying as the controls seemed to change for ech gun when they needn't for example to insert a magizene for one pistol is z while to insert a barrel into a magnum its r, which simply gets confusing. I often found the enmies, of which there are only two types of too be annoying as well as despite the fact I shoot them with obvious sparks coming off them it still often takes a lot of bullets to take them out, this is very annoying seeing as sometimes you are spawned with one bullet... meaning that you will often spend your time in Receiver walking around its dull landscape, getting shot and starting all over again...

reviewText:
This game is a FPS with elements that allow the user to load and reload their gun manually; although this concept sounded intriguing at first, the gimmick soon wore off and becomes annoying and makes the game a lot more difficult. This game has fairly poor graphics quality but it is on the Unity engine. It has ok gameplay in generated worlds but it is very very difficult to complete. The game pins you against robot enemies in a creepy empty setting where you have to find 11 tapes to complete the one level game.
There isn't much to say about this game due to it's lack of content but it isn't very good.

6/15 Gimmick wears off""

reviewText:
Got this for free on the Humble Store End of Summer Sale, and I'm glad I didn't pay for it. I'm sure there are those who will enjoy this game, but for me I couldn't really get started to even begin enjoying it.

Lots of gun controls that forced me to have to have the help open on the right constantly. Then times when I wasn't sure if the gun was loaded or not. As soon as an enemy shoots you, you die as you have just the tiniest amount of health.

So, spending time wandering around some weird building and dying, whilst not knowing how to use the complicated guns (and often having next to no ammo to begin with), just frustrated me and made me want to go play something else instead. But your mileage may vary, of course. It's just not for me.
