reviewText:
Interesting? Yes.  Fun? No.  Great idea.  Ultimately poor execution.
If it were free, I'd have recommended it. On sale for $1-2, meh-aybe.  Probably not worth $5.

I realize this isn't some triple-A, and I wasn't expecting one.  I don't really regret my $2 spent (on sale).  But if I were to go back I'd probably've skipped this one.  I didn't find the game fun, and often found it frustrating.

The Good: I really enjoyed the fresh take on the FPS, and appreciate the realism.  I hope some of it is incorporated into full-fledged games.  Though only a few pistols, they contain more character than most game's entire arsenals.

The Bad: Gotta hack the Linux version a little if you don't wanna play on a 5 screen.  I have a high-end rig
date: yet performance was somehow a problem.  Its particularly frustrating when you're playing at a crawl-pace to avoid dying (you die so easily and frequently that you're forced to)
recommended: only for the game to stall for a second when you finally encounter a robot and that's that
hoursPlayed: game over.  I was frequently placed in dark portions of the level w/o a flashlight to start w/ (even when you find a flashlight
voteText: it only illuminates ~10 feet or so).  Even after maxing brightness on my monitor I was annoyed w/ how hard it was to see in the darkness.\n\nOh yeah
helpfulPercent: and don't expect anything from the 'story'
votesHelpful: as it consists of tapes w/ an annoyingly borish voice droning on about something I didn't care about (something about how 'dangerously addictive media' had destroyed the world).\n\nIn conclusion
votesTotal: it really is mildly interesting
votesFunny: and I appreciate what the devs did.  Its just more of an experiment/demonstration than a game."

reviewText:
Receiver is a very intresting game. Although the world lacks color, and dispite it's limitations, it's got plenty of action. The game has an unusual feature that you don't see in most FPS's. There's no push-button reloading. You literally have to do each step manually to load your weapon, be it a 1911, a Glock, or a good old fasioned revolver. Dispite how much work it sounds to be, it really adds to the experince.

It also includes a small help feature, which gives suggestions to new players on what the need to do to prep the gun.

This game is well worth the money you spend on it.

reviewText:
For a game made as part of a 7 day challenge, Receiver is pretty impressive.

The Mindkill has taken hold, leaving you to uncover 11 tapes to reveal what happened. This is not as easy as it sounds (it's really damn hard actually). Every time you play, the labyrinth-like building you explore is randomly generated as you play, making no two runs the same.

The most obvious main feature is weapon handling. In this game, you have a gun. I mean REALLY have a gun. If it has parts that can be manipulated, you can manipulate them. Things like safety switches, hammers and even spinning a revolver cylinder around. Learning how to quickly reload a weapon in a combat situation is one of the main challenges of the game.

There are 2 kinds of enemy, each posing their own threats. After playing for a few hours you'll learn to either hate or fear the beep sound they make when they spot you.

Overall this is a very enjoyable game and is great for killing time.
voteText: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Receiver is a really interesting simulation game that should be played by alot of people. In reciever you play as gun wielding spy who needs to find 11 tapes so he can find out how to fight wawes of mind tech robots. In the game theres three guns a revolver, and a glock. Theres also two types of enemies A mind tech turret and a mind tech drone. The game is really fun and the gun mechanics really spice up the gameplay. The first time you reaload your gun you feel the biggest satisfaction. Now about the gameplay. The gameplay is really tight and works fluid. But the difficulty  is insanely difficult. You will want to use cheats that were impilmated in the game. Overall a really fun gun game so go ahead and check it out. I give a 8/10

reviewText:
Fascinating concept for a game. You actually have to manually operate your weapon.

The game is procedurally generated with regards to the placement of enemies, ammunition, and the objective collectibles.

Your success can depend on what weapons, equipment and however much ammo you start with, all of which are random. You can start with anything from a .44 with a dozen rounds, or a 9mm with three measley bullets.

The gunplay is satisfying and tactile, and the game is arranged such that you won't need to do the dozen things involved with operating a gun in a hurry. The pace is slow, and you have as much time as you like to get ready.

It's possible to get up a list of keyboard commands on screen to help you know what to press and what does what.

In all, a great concept, very well designed. Hopefully we see more like this in the future, with more scenarios perhaps, or some sort of multiplayer deathmatch.

Very good price for a couple of hours fun. Definitely pick it up, especially if you catch it on sale.

reviewText:
Never played such a fun fps like this before.
What makes it fun unlike other shooting games is that it shows realism in the gun, and you have to use the gun manualy, and properly.
This game will force you to understand your gun, and how to use it properly and realisticly.
One thing I love about fps's such as these is that the developers are open to new and experimental idea's, such as this game, I encourage more people to make games like this.
This is my favourite type of fps games out of all the rest, it has potential and also has a more thrilling adventure to the weapons itself, unlike other fps games now days.
I just love having the dismay of worring if my weapon was reloaded correctly, or what condition the weapon mode was under, or especially at the times when my gun was nearly out of bullets and I forgot to check and got myself KIA for it.
This game will punish you for any miscalculation or incorrect use of your weapon, and I absolutely adore that!

―NOW WOULD I RECOMMEND THIS?―
Heck yes, I will most definitely, absolutely, positively recommend this game to all fans of guns, fps and simulation.
You wanted a realistic shooter/ simulator, well this game is for you!

reviewText: Receiver is a game that is completely based on one thing: the gun. The gun is both the main character and the antagonist. If you watch a video of this game and think it looks like you would enjoy it, it's very likely that you would.\n\n*EDIT: There are now a number of mods available for the game that make it even more worth playing. Worth the money.

reviewText:
Makes a conscious process out of handling a gun in a FPS game rather than the automated process it usually is. This ads a lot of depth to the gameplay. Wish more games had this.
The cyberpunk feel to the music and setting is nice.
The only thing negative about this game is that it's basically a proof of concept/tech demo. The randomized enemy placement and equipment makes it worthwhile playing the game repeatedly, but it otherwise lacks most things a real game would have (including textures).
Still, it's a lot of fun and something everyone interested in FPS genre should try.

reviewText:
>>Hey fanboys, can you stop putting thumbs down because I don't like your silly video game? I'm fairly certain most of you giving this a thumbs down have already bought the game /before/ I put this review here.

Receiver is an interesting firearms simulator video game but it falls short of it's goals with poor execution. I suppose you get what you pay for. Don't always expect just $5 to get you a good video game.

GAMEPLAY: You spawn in a random location with a random pistol with a random amount of ammo. The goal is to find six randomly-placed casette tapes in a randomly-generated map with randomly-placed robot enemies (taser-bots & stationary machine gun turrets). There's ammo randomly placed around the map. You must manipulate every part of your gun with your keyboard. There's no lean feature, so you must expose your entire body in order to get a few shots off at a robot. Considering that you die no matter where you are shot, this becomes extremely problematic. The randomly-generated maps don't fit the gameplay well; you can easily get stuck in odd places thanks to the bizzare level design. Stairs are nightmarish.

PRESENTATION: The game is full of plain, blank textures which have no depth whatsoever. Low-detail textures can look good sometimes (see: Unturned) but this game is trying to create a realistic apartment complex. Without the textures, though, every surface looks like plastic. The skybox is low detail and ugly as sin. The sound effects and music are good, but unfortunately, do little to correct the visual sins.

STORY: Hardly any story at all. The little story you can get is from the randomly-placed casette tapes. It's just a guy reading from a script in the most boring and monotonous voice thought possible. It sounds like he just got up at 6:30 AM and didn't have his coffee yet.

THE VERDICT: You should really shell out some extra money in order to get you a better video game. This game doesn't teach you much about actually fighting since there's no human enemies. You can learn how to work a pistol, but if you're the kind of guy who finds this game interesting, you should already know how to use a gun.

reviewText: you know, I bought this game, beacouse it has a great idea of accually full controll. But a good idea doesn't mean a good game. when I first launched it, all I said was: HOW DO I WHAT? of course you shoot with the left click, but to do as easy things as reloading your gun you MUST learn a 6-7 button combination, witch makes you dead if you have to reload with any enemy around. As for the enemyes there is a turret and a drone. Its easy to deal with the turrets, but if you see a drone... consider yourself dead. There are many guns, but some of them are hardly functional. There are NO skins whatsoever, except for a few dark colors on the enemies. The fact that its a rooftop at night doesn't mean you don't need other colors than grey. After an hour I ended up just turning my flashligt on and off constantly at a wall, just so I can see something else than that one shade of grey. That is IF you have a flashlight. What I  mean is that levels are random each time, and so is your inventory. That goes so far that you can spawn without ANY AMMO, with or without a flashlight, and a game can go on for hours or just five minutes depending on lootdrop, and if you find it or not. Collectables shine and are easy to find most of the times.\n\nIn conclusion I't simular to the virtual boy, it can cause headache (if you're sanity is easily disturbed hallucination)due to a lack of colors. the game is really instable both with the random generation, and with crashes. Its another game that could have been great, but they just rushed it as a joke. Or if you want to mke a joke of it at least don't ask money for it!

reviewText: So... here's Receiver.  It was created in 7 days.  It is almost entirely about handling guns in an extremely complex and realistic fashion.  It is also about randomly-assembled levels, and listening to cassette tapes, and not being able to see anything.  In some ways it's the very definition of a proof-of-concept game.  The focus is set squarely on the novelty of manipulating firearms realistically.  Everything else is sparse window dressing.  But then, that everything else" isn't necessarily bad.  It's highly unique as well.  So in that sense Receiver is more than just a proof-of-concept game... but it's less than a game.  It's something in between.\n\nRead more[videogamepotpourri.blogspot.com]"

reviewText:
(on a quick not me and a freind spent nearly an hour on this game at his house, i just got on long enough to right a review)

This game is trash.  But it has such good patential.  Fist off this small game sits there trying to be Arma.  How?  Let me walk you through how to reload a revolver: hold right cliick to raise gun> E to open chamber> hold G to dump spent casings> Z to add a bullet to the chamber> E to close chamber> release right click.  So why is that bad?  There is no tutorial, no instructions, no objective reminder.  you are thrown into an ugly world with a gun, no ammo, no clue how to get ammo, OP enemies that kill you with 1 shot but take 5 to kill.  After watching videoes we understand our objective and how to play, in this stealth game, you can't stay quite.

overall i give a 1/10 because i don't think even the appropreate audiance would like this.

reviewText: Receiver is  not a game that everyone will enjoy. Sure, it's repetitive, graphics aren't very good and it's very hard. But if you are a gun enthusiast or simply enjoy a challenge and have the patience to master the complex gun mechanics, you will most likely have fun playing it. The developers tried to do something different from other first person shooter games and they achieved it (in seven days), and it's good to see new ideas on the fps market.

reviewText:
This game is more a less a rogue-like tech demo. The price and the videos about it should reflect that to players.

The premise of the game is that players will start off with a pistol, it could be a revolver base or a magazine based pistol.  From there, you are going around looking for recordings to find out more about the area that you are trying to escape.  Casing point though, it takes a backseat to the mechanics.

One of the core concepts of this demo" is that it is fairly thrilling to reload a pistol all the way through by manipulating each of its mechanisms in a fluid manner under pressure. The hammer
recommended:
the loading or unloading of the magazine all have dedicated buttons which gives this demo a big learning curve because it's not as simple as press "R" to reload your magazines anymore.

The revolvers are simpler and take less time to learn to reload and ready for firing.

As for the other parts of the game
hoursPlayed: the elements of the environment and the mechanical enemies are simple polygons.  It gets the job done."

reviewText:
Obligatory header to the review: I focus on four primary areas whenever I review a game: gameplay, story, graphics, and sound/audio/general things that go into your earholes. Gameplay and Story get a rating scale from 1 to 10, and the AV stuff gets a rating from 1 to 5. My philosophy on this is that there are some instances in which a game may not necessarily have that much in the way of gameplay (take Amnesia for example), but the story/atmosphere/whatever it may be is reason enough to pick it up. Also, take the cumulative score with a grain of salt; it's just a numerical feeling about the game as a whole. That's part of why I do these subscores. Also, keep in mind that I'm not going off of school grade based rankings. A 5/10 denotes what I feel to be an average game. Likewise, 7/10 is a game that I think is pretty cool, and something that gets a 2/10 is near-abomination level. Pinning scores to an even further obfuscated rating scale is kinda senseless, but for the sake of my backloggery, I'll repeat again that 1.0-2.7 is a one-star game, 3.0-4.7 is a two-star game, 5.0-6.7, 7.0-8.7, and 9.0-10 are three, four, and five stars, respectively.

Gameplay: Definitely one of the more interesting FPSes I've played. It's easily described as Slender but with guns, and while that's not bad, it does miss what this game is truly about, which is to emulate gun mechanics as accurately as possible. No longer in this game are you able to press the easy reload button. Instead, you have to go through the motions for each and every gun. While that may sound tedious, it's actually pretty fun in execution. Much like Slender, this game does have a very randomized nature to it, which can be both a benefit and a downfall. It's always disappointing being met with three turrets in a row whenever you've only got three bullets in your magazine. This game can be completed relatively quickly (hence the short playtime, but there's another reason for that), but it's still a pretty fun game nonetheless. 7/10.

Story: Hey guys, do you like The Matrix? If so, you'll be able to tell ALL of the inspirations"! But hey

reviewText: Receiver's fun. You run around shooting these sneaky little robots. The twist is that the gun that you weild is painfully realistic. Quite a few firearm mechanics come into play in this game. For someone like me who has shot guns quite a bit(FAR from an expert with guns though), I picked up on it pretty quick. For someone with less knowledge about firearms, these mechanics may take awhile to learn and might be frustrating. But that's the game really. It's less about the robots and more about you maneuvering this machine you're shooting them with. You have to remember all the steps of reloading in order and have to be able to do it fast. The game looks nice. It's going for a minimalistic style which it achieves nicely(at least to my eyes).\nHowever, it's HORRIBLY optimized. You've probably heard this from the bad reviews, and what they say is true. For how it looks and how much is going on, this game should not run my graphics card hotter than Battlefeild at a lower frame rate. As long as you have a decent system that can run this, you'll be fine, but it's still rediculous none the less. There's also problems with the map spawning to. I sometimes find myself getting stuck in certain areas and have to restart because there's no place to go. With all it's problems, it's still amazingly fun. Don't let all of this deter you. If you have $5, go for it. It's a few hours entertainment for less than the cost of a movie ticket.
